“If the Earth was destroyed, like it was in Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, what effect would it have on the solar system?” We have this “historical record” on the destruction of Earth by the Vogons:  It seems that the particular method employed by the Vogons simply made most of the mass of the Earth “go away” with a small firework where the planet’s core used to be. That seems to mean that there would be no bombardment of other planets by fragments of Earth, no ring around the Sun, just a little bit of cooling ash from the firework. What happens to the ash? We do not see the Moon destroyed- since it also orbits the Sun, it would likely continue to do so with the kinks in its orbit currently caused by Earth’s presence smoothed into a nice circle. Oh, you didn’t know the Moon orbits the Sun?  Image showing correct and incorrect illustrations of the Moon's orbit from Young's Manual on Astronomy [7]. Figure 66 in the image correctly represents the Moon's orbital path always concave toward the sun. Figure 67 incorrectly represents the Moon's orbit with a shorter period and always concave toward the Earth. Figure 68 incorrectly represents the Moon completing loops around the Earth. (researchgate) Since we know that the Vogons were conned into destroying Earth by a psychiatrist who feared his profession would be made obsolete if The Question were known, it stands to reason that he wouldn’t bother specifying that the Moon be destroyed (since it wasn’t part of the computer that was built to deduce The Question. Anyway, the firework ash remaining from Earth’s destruction would quite naturally obey the laws of gravity and fall toward the nearest gravitating mass, the Moon. As for the rest of the Solar system, it was once thought that the Earth and Venus were in a sort of resonance in which Venus orbited the Sun 13 times for each 8 times Earth did. This is not quite true because the orbital periods of both planets aren’t in perfect ratio. If they were, it would be possible that removing the Earth could destabilize the orbit of Venus. The Earth and mars are in a similar “near-resonance” of almost 15:8 (15 Earth years per 8 Mars years. Hence removing Earth could destabilize Mars’ orbit if Earth were removed if the orbits were in perfect ratio. But they aren’t, so it won’t. Orbital resonance - Wikipedia All the other bodies, with the exception of a few asteroids which cross the orbit of the Earth as they orbit the Sun, are always too far from Earth for its absence (or presence) to have sensible effect on them. There are a few asteroids in resonance with Earth and Venus, like 1685 Toro, that will have to find a new orbit with Earth removed. 1685 Toro - Wikipedia Other than that, removing the Earth will have no effect on the rest of the Solar system.
